nodes.text: The Naive Bayes classifier is an effective and reliable method for identifying and filtering spam emails on a combined dataset
Spam email prevalence disrupts communication and poses security risks, motivating automated detection methods
Naive Bayes is a text classification method that applies Bayes rule with a conditional independence assumption to compute class posterior probabilities from word likelihoods and class priors
Data preprocessing pipeline: text cleaning (remove punctuation, HTML, stop words; lowercase), tokenization into words, and feature extraction using Bag of Words to produce word-frequency vectors

Study dataset: combined 2007 TREC Public Spam Corpus and Enron-Spam dataset with 83,446 emails (43,910 spam, 39,538 ham) split randomly 80% train (66,756) / 20% test (16,690) preserving class proportions
Word likelihoods are estimated by tallying term frequencies per class and applying Laplace smoothing (add-one) to avoid zero probabilities
The classifier predicts by computing product of per-word likelihoods given a class, multiplying by class prior, and selecting the class with higher posterior probability
Training/testing split resulted in train: 35,128 spam and 31,630 ham; test: 8,782 spam and 7,908 ham
Class priors computed as class message counts divided by total messages in the dataset
Model evaluation used 5-fold cross-validation to select best-performing fold and then evaluated the selected model on the held-out test subset
Cross-validation accuracies across folds: 0.9733, 0.9766, 0.9762, 0.9759, 0.9755 with mean about 0.9751, indicating stable performance
Selected model (fold 2) achieved overall test accuracy of 97.82% on the test subset
Confusion matrix test outcomes: ham (7908 tested) -> 7800 true negatives, 108 false positives; spam (8782 tested) -> 8526 true positives, 256 false negatives
Per-class performance: ham accuracy 98.64%; spam accuracy 97.08%; precision, recall, and F1-score approximately 0.98 for both classes (macro and weighted averages 0.98)

Conclusion: Naive Bayes exhibited high precision, recall, F1, and stable accuracy on this combined dataset, making it a well-suited and reliable approach for spam detection in many real-world applications

Future work and limitations: potential improvements include exploring hybrid models with SVM or deep learning and adding contextual and semantic analysis to address limitations of the independence assumption
